chunks.topic: Call Options - Official Definition
chunks.content: CBOE Official Definition: A call option gives the buyer the RIGHT (not obligation) to BUY 100 shares of the underlying security at a specified strike price before or on the expiration date. The call seller (writer) has the OBLIGATION to SELL shares at the strike if assigned. Contract specifications: 1 contract = 100 shares. Settlement: T+1 for options trades, T+2 for stock delivery on exercise. American-style calls can be exercised any time before expiration; European-style only at expiration. Exercise methods: (1) Automatic exercise if ITM by $0.01+ at expiration (OCC rule). (2) Manual exercise by contacting broker before expiration cutoff (typically 5:30 PM ET). (3) Do Not Exercise instruction if you want to let ITM option expire worthless. CBOE trading hours: 9:30 AM - 4:00 PM ET (equity options), 9:30 AM - 4:15 PM ET (index options).

chunks.topic: Put Options - Official Definition
chunks.content: CBOE Official Definition: A put option gives the buyer the RIGHT (not obligation) to SELL 100 shares of the underlying security at a specified strike price before or on the expiration date. The put seller (writer) has the OBLIGATION to BUY shares at the strike if assigned. Contract specifications: 1 contract = 100 shares. Put-call parity relationship: C - P = S - K*e^(-rT), where C=call price, P=put price, S=stock price, K=strike, r=risk-free rate, T=time to expiration. Exercise styles: American-style (most equity options) exercisable anytime; European-style (most index options) exercisable only at expiration. Early exercise considerations: Rarely optimal for calls (except deep ITM before ex-dividend). More common for puts if intrinsic value > time value remaining. Assignment: Random by OCC if multiple sellers, then assigned proportionally or randomly by broker.

chunks.topic: Settlement Procedures - Physical vs Cash
chunks.content: CBOE Settlement Methods: (1) PHYSICAL SETTLEMENT (Equity Options): Exercise results in actual stock delivery. Buyer receives/delivers 100 shares per contract. Settlement T+2 after exercise. Requires sufficient cash (for put exercise) or shares (for call exercise). (2) CASH SETTLEMENT (Index Options like SPX, VIX, RUT): No stock delivery. Exercised contracts settled in cash = (Index value - Strike) x $100 multiplier. Settlement based on opening print (AM-settled) or closing value (PM-settled). Example SPX settlement: Long 4500 call, SPX settles at 4550 = (4550-4500) x $100 = $5,000 cash credit. (3) PM-SETTLEMENT: Uses closing index value on expiration Friday. Standard SPX options (SPXW monthly). (4) AM-SETTLEMENT: Uses SET (Special Opening Quotation) on expiration Friday morning. SPX standard monthly options expire AM-settled. Critical: Verify settlement style before trading index options.

chunks.topic: Expiration Cycles - Monthly, Weekly, Daily
chunks.content: CBOE Expiration Types: (1) STANDARD MONTHLY: Third Friday of each month (or Thursday if Friday is exchange holiday). Most liquid options with longest history. Trade until 4:00 PM ET on expiration day. (2) WEEKLY OPTIONS (Weeklys): Introduced 2005, now available on 500+ underlyings. Expire every Friday (except third Friday - that's monthly). Listed Thursday and expire following Friday (8 days). Lower premium, higher flexibility. Symbol suffix '1', '2', '3', '4', '5' for week of month. (3) QUARTERLY OPTIONS (QQQs): Expire last trading day of quarter (Mar, Jun, Sep, Dec). Often used by institutions for hedge accounting. (4) END-OF-MONTH (EOM): Expire last trading day of each month. (5) DAILY EXPIRATIONS (SPX): Available on SPX for every trading day. Zero-day options (0DTE) introduced 2022. Highest gamma risk, fastest theta decay. Expiration day pin risk: At-the-money options on expiration day create hedging flows that can pin stock price to strike.

chunks.topic: Market vs Limit Orders for Options
chunks.content: CBOE Order Types - Market vs Limit: (1) MARKET ORDER: Executes immediately at best available price. Risk: Wide bid-ask spreads can cause significant slippage. CBOE warning: Market orders in options can execute at prices far from NBBO (National Best Bid Offer) during fast markets. Use ONLY in highly liquid options (SPY, QQQ, AAPL). (2) LIMIT ORDER: Specifies maximum price (buy) or minimum price (sell). Only executes at limit price or better. Protects against slippage but may not fill. CBOE best practice: Always use limit orders for options trading. (3) MARKETABLE LIMIT: Limit order priced to execute immediately (buy at ask, sell at bid). Combines urgency with price protection. (4) STOP ORDER: Triggers market order when stop price reached. Not recommended for options due to gaps and slippage. (5) STOP-LIMIT: Triggers limit order when stop price reached. Better than stop but may not fill. Execution priority: Price-time priority on CBOE. Orders at same price filled FIFO (first in, first out).

chunks.topic: Spread Orders and Complex Order Handling
chunks.content: CBOE Complex Order Trading: (1) SPREAD ORDER: Single order to execute multi-leg strategy at net debit or credit. Example: Buy $100 call, Sell $105 call for $2.00 net debit. Ensures both legs fill simultaneously at desired spread price. Prevents 'legging risk' (one leg fills, other doesn't). (2) CBOE COMPLEX ORDER BOOK (COB): Introduced 1999, enhanced continuously. Allows up to 100 legs in single order. Hybrid execution model combines electronic and floor broker. (3) SPREAD TYPES: Vertical (same expiration, different strikes), Horizontal/Calendar (same strike, different expirations), Diagonal (different strikes and expirations). (4) CONTINGENT ORDERS: One-cancels-other (OCO): Two orders, if one fills, other cancels. One-triggers-other (OTO): If first order fills, triggers second order. Bracket orders: Entry with simultaneous profit target and stop loss. (5) CBOE BEST PRACTICE: Always trade spreads as single spread order, never leg individually. Complex orders may receive price improvement in COB auction.

chunks.topic: Reg-T Margin Requirements for Options
chunks.content: CBOE/FINRA Regulation T Margin: (1) LONG OPTIONS: Must be paid in full (100% of premium). No margin allowed - options cannot be margined. Expire if not paid by settlement. (2) COVERED CALLS: No margin required if you own underlying stock. Full stock value must be in account. (3) CASH-SECURED PUTS: Must maintain cash = strike price x 100 x number of contracts. Example: Sell 5 contracts $50 puts = $25,000 cash required. (4) NAKED CALLS: Margin = 100% of option proceeds + (20% of underlying value - OTM amount). Example: Sell $110 call on $100 stock for $2 = $200 + (20% x $10,000) - $1,000 = $1,200 margin. PLUS underlying must be marginable security. (5) NAKED PUTS: Margin = 100% of option proceeds + (20% of strike price - OTM amount). Minimum margin: 10% of strike price. (6) SPREADS: Margin = Maximum loss on spread. Example: $5-wide credit spread = $500 margin - credit received. CBOE warning: Naked options have unlimited risk (calls) or strike-limited risk (puts) and require highest approval level.

chunks.topic: Portfolio Margin - Benefits and Requirements
chunks.content: CBOE Portfolio Margin Program: (1) DEFINITION: Risk-based margin calculation using theoretical pricing models. Approved 2007 by SEC for accounts >$100,000 (raised to $125,000 in 2020). (2) CALCULATION METHOD: Uses 10-point price range scan (underlying moves ±10% for stocks, ±6-8% for broad indexes). Calculates worst-case loss across all scenarios. Margin = Largest theoretical loss. (3) BENEFITS: Typically 50-75% lower margin than Reg-T for hedged positions. Offsets: Longs vs shorts, puts vs calls recognized. Correlation between positions considered. (4) REQUIREMENTS: Minimum $125,000 equity to open, $100,000 to maintain. Highest options approval level. Broker approval required. (5) RISKS: Larger position sizes possible = larger potential losses. Intraday margin calls possible (real-time calculation). House liquidation possible if margin deficit. (6) CBOE EXAMPLE: Iron Condor margin: Reg-T = $1,000 (5-point spread). Portfolio margin = $250-400 (based on risk scan). 60-75% reduction. Best for: Sophisticated traders with hedged, defined-risk strategies.

chunks.topic: VIX Calculation Methodology
chunks.content: CBOE Volatility Index (VIX) Calculation: (1) INTRODUCTION: VIX launched 1993, recalculated with current methodology 2003. Measures market's expectation of 30-day forward volatility. Derived from SPX (S&P 500 Index) option prices. (2) CALCULATION: Uses strip of out-of-the-money SPX puts and calls spanning two expiration months. Weights options by strike to create variance swap replication. Formula: Interpolates near-term and next-term variance to constant 30-day maturity. Square root of variance = VIX. (3) INPUTS: SPX options with 23-37 days to expiration (near-term) and next monthly expiration (next-term). Only uses options with non-zero bid prices. Weights inversely proportional to strike squared (Δk/k²). (4) INTERPRETATION: VIX = 20 means market expects 20% annualized volatility over next 30 days. Daily expected move = VIX / √365 = 20 / 19.1 = ~1.05%. VIX >30 = high volatility/fear. VIX <15 = complacency. (5) IMPORTANT: VIX measures IMPLIED volatility, not realized volatility. Cannot directly trade VIX - must use VIX futures or options.

chunks.topic: VIX Futures and Options - Trading Mechanics
chunks.content: CBOE VIX Derivatives: (1) VIX FUTURES: Launched 2004. Cash-settled contracts based on VIX Special Opening Quotation (SOQ). Contract size: $1,000 x VIX Index. Tick size: 0.05 index points = $50. Settlement: Final settlement value uses VIX SOQ on Wednesday morning (expiration day). (2) VIX OPTIONS: Launched 2006. European-style (exercise only at expiration). Underlying: VIX futures, NOT spot VIX. Cash-settled. Exercise settlement value: VIX SOQ on Wednesday morning. (3) VIX TERM STRUCTURE: Front-month futures typically trade above spot VIX (contango) in calm markets. Steep contango = market expects volatility to decrease. Backwardation = front-month lower than back months (fear/stress). (4) CONTANGO COST: VIX futures mean-revert to spot VIX. Contango = daily decay in long VIX positions. VXX and other VIX ETPs lose value in contango (~5-10% monthly). (5) TRADING STRATEGIES: Long VIX calls for tail risk hedge (uncorrelated to stocks). Short VIX calls for premium income (high risk). Calendar spreads to profit from term structure. CBOE WARNING: VIX derivatives are NOT the same as spot VIX.

chunks.topic: SPX vs SPY Options - Critical Differences
chunks.content: CBOE SPX vs SPY Comparison: (1) UNDERLYING: SPX = S&P 500 Index (theoretical basket of 500 stocks). SPY = SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust (actual tradable security). (2) SETTLEMENT: SPX = Cash-settled (no stock delivery). SPY = Physical settlement (delivers SPY shares). (3) EXERCISE STYLE: SPX = European (exercise only at expiration). SPY = American (exercise anytime). (4) CONTRACT SIZE: SPX = $100 x Index (~$450,000 notional at 4500). SPY = 100 shares (~$45,000 notional at $450). SPX ≈ 10x SPY in notional value. (5) TAX TREATMENT: SPX = Section 1256 contracts (60% long-term, 40% short-term capital gains). SPY = Ordinary capital gains treatment. Section 1256 advantage: ~60% of gains taxed at lower LTCG rate regardless of holding period. (6) EXPIRATION: SPX standard monthlies = AM-settled (SET value on Friday morning). SPX weeklys (SPXW) = PM-settled (closing value Friday). SPY = PM-settled (closes at 4:00 PM ET). (7) LIQUIDITY: SPY typically tighter bid-ask spreads (more retail). SPX larger sizes available (more institutional). CBOE GUIDANCE: Use SPX for tax efficiency and cash settlement, SPY for smaller size and flexibility.

chunks.topic: Cash Settlement vs Physical Delivery
chunks.content: CBOE Settlement Types Comparison: (1) CASH SETTLEMENT (Index Options): Exercise results in cash payment = intrinsic value. No stock or ETF shares change hands. Settlement formula: (Settlement Value - Strike) x Multiplier. Example: Long SPX 4500 call, settles at 4550 = (4550 - 4500) x $100 = $5,000. No assignment risk for sellers (cash automatically debited). No pin risk at expiration (no delta hedging needed). (2) PHYSICAL SETTLEMENT (Equity/ETF Options): Exercise results in stock delivery (calls) or stock purchase (puts). Buyer receives/delivers 100 shares per contract. Requires margin/cash for settlement. Assignment risk for sellers (random selection by OCC). Pin risk near expiration (market makers hedging creates price pressure). (3) ADVANTAGES - Cash Settlement: No assignment surprise. Tax efficiency (Section 1256 for indexes). Lower transaction costs (no stock commissions). Portfolio management easier (no stock positions created). (4) ADVANTAGES - Physical Settlement: Can convert to stock ownership. Flexibility for stock ownership strategies (wheel, covered calls). Smaller contract sizes available. (5) CBOE CAUTION: Verify settlement type before trading. Index options settle in cash; equity options settle in stock.

chunks.topic: European vs American Style Options
chunks.content: CBOE Exercise Style Comparison: (1) AMERICAN-STYLE OPTIONS: Can be exercised ANY time before expiration (including intraday). Most equity options (AAPL, TSLA, etc.). Most ETF options (SPY, QQQ, IWM). Flexibility for option holder. Assignment risk for sellers at any time. Early exercise possible for: Deep ITM calls before ex-dividend. Deep ITM puts when intrinsic value > time value. (2) EUROPEAN-STYLE OPTIONS: Can ONLY be exercised at expiration. Most index options (SPX, NDX, RUT). VIX options and futures. Cannot be exercised early (even if deep ITM). No early assignment risk for sellers. Position management easier (no surprise assignments). (3) PRICING IMPACT: European options sometimes trade at discount to American (cannot capture dividends early). American calls on dividend-paying stocks command premium for early exercise right. (4) STRATEGY IMPLICATIONS: European eliminates early assignment risk - sellers can hold through expiration with confidence. American requires monitoring for early assignment (especially near ex-dividend). (5) CBOE RULE: OCC automatically exercises options ITM by $0.01+ at expiration (both styles). Can submit Do Not Exercise instruction to prevent. CBOE GUIDANCE: Check exercise style before trading - affects risk management significantly.

chunks.topic: Section 1256 Tax Treatment for Index Options
chunks.content: CBOE/IRS Section 1256 Contracts: (1) DEFINITION: IRC Section 1256 provides preferential tax treatment for certain derivatives. Broad-based index options (SPX, NDX, RUT, VIX) qualify. Equity and narrow-based index options (SPY, QQQ) do NOT qualify. (2) TAX TREATMENT: 60% of gains/losses taxed as long-term capital gains (0%, 15%, or 20% rate). 40% of gains/losses taxed as short-term capital gains (ordinary income rate). Applies REGARDLESS of holding period (even day trades). Example: $10,000 SPX profit = $6,000 LTCG + $4,000 STCG. Effective tax rate: ~23% (vs 37% for SPY at highest bracket). (3) MARK-TO-MARKET: All open Section 1256 positions marked to market on Dec 31. Unrealized gains/losses recognized for tax year. Must report even if position held into next year. (4) QUALIFIED INDEXES: S&P 500 Index (SPX), Nasdaq-100 Index (NDX), Russell 2000 Index (RUT), VIX, CBOE Volatility Index derivatives. Must be broad-based (at least 9 stocks, diversified). (5) REPORTING: Form 6781 (Gains and Losses from Section 1256 Contracts). Separate from Schedule D for regular capital gains. CBOE BENEFIT: SPX options save ~13% tax vs SPY options for high earners (37% vs ~24% effective rate).

chunks.topic: Characteristics and Risks of Standardized Options - Official OCC Document
chunks.content: CBOE/OCC Required Risk Disclosure: (1) OFFICIAL DOCUMENT: 'Characteristics and Risks of Standardized Options' (OCC options disclosure document, ODD). Required reading before opening options account. Updated periodically - current edition available at www.cboe.com/risk-disclosure. (2) KEY RISKS DISCLOSED: Options can expire worthless (100% loss of premium paid). Sellers face unlimited risk (naked calls) or substantial risk (naked puts). Time decay accelerates near expiration. Volatility changes affect option values. Liquidity risk in less-active options. (3) SUITABILITY: Options not suitable for all investors. Broker must approve based on: Financial situation, Investment experience, Trading objectives, Risk tolerance. Approval levels: Level 1 (covered calls, cash-secured puts), Level 2 (long options), Level 3 (spreads), Level 4 (naked options). (4) REGULATORY OVERSIGHT: CBOE regulated by SEC as national securities exchange. OCC (Options Clearing Corporation) guarantees all option contracts. FINRA oversees broker-dealers and customer accounts. (5) CBOE REQUIREMENT: All customers MUST receive ODD before trading. Signature required acknowledging receipt and understanding of risks. Failure to provide = regulatory violation.

chunks.topic: Assignment Risk and Mechanics
chunks.content: CBOE/OCC Assignment Process: (1) ASSIGNMENT DEFINITION: When option seller must fulfill contract obligation. Short call → Must sell/deliver 100 shares at strike. Short put → Must buy 100 shares at strike. (2) ASSIGNMENT TRIGGERS: Automatic exercise by OCC if option ITM by $0.01+ at expiration. Early exercise by long option holder (American-style only). Discretionary exercise (even if OTM) by submitting exercise notice. (3) ASSIGNMENT SELECTION: OCC assigns to clearing member firms with short positions. Firms assign to customers via random or FIFO method (broker determines). No way to predict which specific account assigned. (4) ASSIGNMENT TIMING: Notice of assignment received next business day after exercise. Stock settlement occurs T+2 after exercise. Early assignment typically occurs after market close (reviewed ~6 PM ET). (5) EARLY ASSIGNMENT RISK FACTORS: Deep ITM options (intrinsic value >> time value). Options on stocks with upcoming ex-dividend date (call holders exercise to capture dividend). European-style options (SPX, NDX) have NO early assignment risk. (6) CBOE GUIDANCE: Monitor short positions daily for assignment risk. Close ITM short positions before expiration to avoid assignment. Ensure sufficient margin/cash to handle assignment. Early assignment rare but possible - plan accordingly.

chunks.topic: Pin Risk Near Expiration
chunks.content: CBOE Pin Risk Disclosure: (1) DEFINITION: Pin risk = risk of stock 'pinning' to strike price at expiration due to market maker hedging activity. Creates uncertainty about assignment. Stock closing exactly at strike = unclear if option ITM or OTM. (2) MECHANICS: Market makers short options hedge by buying/selling underlying stock. As expiration approaches, delta hedging becomes aggressive. Large open interest at specific strike creates buying/selling pressure pushing stock toward that strike. Stock may settle exactly at strike or oscillate around it. (3) ASSIGNMENT UNCERTAINTY: Stock closes at $50.00, you're short $50 calls. Are you assigned? Depends on final settlement price and after-hours movement. You may be assigned on some contracts but not all (partial assignment). Won't know until next day. (4) PIN RISK CONSEQUENCES: Cannot predict if you'll own stock next day. May need to buy/sell stock Monday at unfavorable price. Gap risk over weekend. Margin implications if assigned. (5) CBOE RISK MITIGATION: Close positions with strikes near stock price before 4 PM on expiration day. Especially critical for spreads (may be assigned on one leg but not other). Roll position to later expiration. Use European-style index options to eliminate pin risk. (6) CBOE WARNING: Pin risk highest on high-volume expiration days with large open interest. Monitor positions closely on expiration Friday.

chunks.topic: Liquidity Risk and Bid-Ask Spreads
chunks.content: CBOE Liquidity Considerations: (1) LIQUIDITY DEFINITION: Ability to enter/exit position at fair price without significant slippage. Measured by: Bid-ask spread width, Average daily volume, Open interest. (2) BID-ASK SPREAD: Difference between highest bid (buyer price) and lowest ask (seller price). Example: Bid $2.00, Ask $2.20 = $0.20 spread (10% of mid-price). Wide spreads = high transaction cost. CBOE rule of thumb: Spread should be <5-10% of option price for good liquidity. (3) FACTORS AFFECTING LIQUIDITY: Underlying popularity (SPY very liquid, small-caps illiquid). Strike selection (ATM most liquid, deep ITM/OTM less liquid). Expiration date (near-term most liquid, LEAPs less liquid). Time of day (open/close most liquid, mid-day less). Market conditions (volatility spikes reduce liquidity). (4) LIQUIDITY RISKS: Wide spreads increase cost to enter/exit. Market orders can execute at terrible prices. May not be able to exit position at fair value. Forced to hold illiquid position through expiration. (5) CBOE MARKET MAKERS: Designated Primary Market Makers (DPMs) provide liquidity. Obligated to maintain two-sided markets. Spreads widen when DMMs pull quotes (fast markets). (6) CBOE BEST PRACTICES: Only trade options with daily volume >1,000 contracts. Verify bid-ask spread before entry. Use limit orders exclusively. Avoid illiquid underlyings and far-dated expirations.

chunks.topic: The Greeks - Delta, Gamma, Theta, Vega
chunks.content: CBOE Options Greeks Reference: (1) DELTA: Rate of change of option price relative to $1 change in underlying. Calls: 0 to +1.00 (ITM calls approach 1.00). Puts: -1.00 to 0 (ITM puts approach -1.00). Also represents approximate probability of expiring ITM. 0.30 delta = ~30% chance of expiring ITM. Portfolio delta = sum of all position deltas (measures directional risk). (2) GAMMA: Rate of change of delta relative to $1 change in underlying. Highest for ATM options near expiration. Long options = positive gamma (delta increases as stock moves favorably). Short options = negative gamma (delta works against you). Gamma risk increases dramatically in final week. (3) THETA: Rate of option value decay per day (time decay). Always negative for long options (you lose value each day). Always positive for short options (you gain value each day). Accelerates near expiration (non-linear). ATM options have highest theta. (4) VEGA: Change in option value per 1% change in implied volatility. Long options = positive vega (benefit from IV increase). Short options = negative vega (hurt by IV increase). Higher for longer-dated options. ATM options have highest vega. (5) CBOE GUIDANCE: Greeks work in combination - cannot analyze in isolation. Portfolio Greeks show overall risk exposure. Use position analysis tools to monitor Greeks continuously.

chunks.topic: Implied Volatility - Definition and Trading Implications
chunks.content: CBOE Implied Volatility Framework: (1) DEFINITION: Implied Volatility (IV) = market's expectation of future volatility derived from option prices. Uses Black-Scholes model in reverse: Input option price → Solve for volatility. NOT a prediction of direction, only magnitude of expected moves. (2) IV vs HISTORICAL VOLATILITY: Historical Volatility (HV) = actual past price movement (standard deviation of returns). IV often differs from HV (forward-looking vs backward-looking). IV typically HIGHER than HV (volatility risk premium). (3) IV PERCENTILE/RANK: IV Rank = (Current IV - 52-week IV low) / (52-week IV high - 52-week IV low) x 100. IV Percentile = percentage of days in past year IV was below current IV. High IV Rank (>50) = expensive options, favor selling premium. Low IV Rank (<50) = cheap options, favor buying options. (4) VOLATILITY SMILE/SKEW: OTM puts typically have higher IV than ATM/OTM calls (fear of downside). Creates volatility skew on chart. Reflects crash risk premium and supply/demand imbalance. (5) VIX RELATIONSHIP: VIX measures SPX implied volatility (30-day weighted). High VIX (>30) = high SPX option IV = option premium expensive. Low VIX (<15) = low SPX option IV = option premium cheap. (6) CBOE TRADING PRINCIPLE: Sell premium when IV high (reversion to mean). Buy options when IV low (expect expansion). Check IV rank/percentile before every trade.

chunks.topic: CBOE Trading Hours and After-Hours Settlement
chunks.content: CBOE Trading Session Details: (1) REGULAR TRADING HOURS: Equity options: 9:30 AM - 4:00 PM ET (aligns with stock market). Index options: 9:30 AM - 4:15 PM ET (extra 15 minutes for SPX, NDX, RUT). VIX options/futures: 9:30 AM - 4:15 PM ET. (2) EXTENDED HOURS TRADING: Select ETF options (SPY, QQQ, IWM): After-hours trading 4:00 PM - 5:00 PM ET via CBOE Global Trading Hours (GTH). Limited to most liquid products. Lower liquidity and wider spreads during extended hours. (3) EXPIRATION DAY CUTOFFS: Equity options: Trading stops 4:00 PM ET on expiration day. Index AM-settled options (SPX monthly): Trading stops 4:15 PM ET day BEFORE expiration (Thursday). Index PM-settled options (SPXW): Trading stops 4:15 PM ET on expiration Friday. Exercise instructions deadline: Typically 5:30 PM ET (broker-specific). (4) SETTLEMENT TIMES: Options trades settle T+1 (next business day). Stock delivery from exercise settles T+2. Cash settlement from index options: Next business day. (5) CBOE AFTER-HOURS RISK: Stock continues trading after 4 PM (until 8 PM in extended hours). Option position frozen but underlying moves. Assignment decisions made based on after-hours stock movement. Cannot adjust option position if stock gaps after hours. (6) CBOE GUIDANCE: Close expiring positions before 4 PM to avoid after-hours risk. Monitor underlying stock in extended hours if holding short options. Verify broker's exercise cutoff time for your account.

chunks.topic: Intrinsic vs Extrinsic Value - Option Premium Components
chunks.content: CBOE Option Value Breakdown: (1) TOTAL OPTION PREMIUM = Intrinsic Value + Extrinsic Value (Time Value). (2) INTRINSIC VALUE: The amount option is in-the-money. Calls: Intrinsic = MAX(Stock Price - Strike Price, 0). Puts: Intrinsic = MAX(Strike Price - Stock Price, 0). Example: $100 stock, $95 call = $5 intrinsic value. Example: $100 stock, $105 put = $5 intrinsic value. ATM and OTM options have ZERO intrinsic value. (3) EXTRINSIC VALUE (TIME VALUE): Premium above intrinsic value. Represents time until expiration + volatility expectations. Formula: Extrinsic = Option Price - Intrinsic Value. Example: $100 stock, $95 call trading at $7 = $5 intrinsic + $2 extrinsic. Factors affecting extrinsic: Time to expiration (more time = more value), Implied volatility (higher IV = more value), Interest rates (minor impact), Dividends (affects call value). (4) TIME DECAY: Extrinsic value decays to $0 at expiration (theta decay). Decay accelerates in final 30 days (non-linear). ATM options have maximum extrinsic value. Deep ITM options mostly intrinsic, minimal extrinsic. Deep OTM options entirely extrinsic (high risk of total loss). (5) CBOE PRINCIPLE: Never pay high extrinsic value for deep ITM options - you're overpaying for time. At expiration, all options worth exactly their intrinsic value (extrinsic = $0).

chunks.topic: Moneyness - In/At/Out of the Money Definitions
chunks.content: CBOE Moneyness Classifications: (1) IN-THE-MONEY (ITM): Option has intrinsic value. Calls: Stock price > Strike price. Puts: Stock price < Strike price. Example: $100 stock, $95 call is $5 ITM. Example: $100 stock, $105 put is $5 ITM. Higher probability of expiring profitable (delta >0.50 for calls). Higher premium than ATM/OTM. More sensitive to stock movement (higher delta). (2) AT-THE-MONEY (ATM): Strike price equals (or very close to) stock price. Highest extrinsic value. Delta approximately 0.50 (50% probability of expiring ITM). Maximum gamma (delta changes fastest). Most liquid strike typically. Highest time decay in absolute dollar terms. (3) OUT-OF-THE-MONEY (OTM): No intrinsic value - premium is all extrinsic. Calls: Stock price < Strike price. Puts: Stock price > Strike price. Example: $100 stock, $105 call is OTM. Example: $100 stock, $95 put is OTM. Lower premium (cheaper to buy). Lower probability of profit (delta <0.50). Higher risk of 100% loss (expires worthless). (4) DEEP IN-THE-MONEY: Multiple strikes in the money (typically 10%+ difference). Delta approaches 1.00 (moves nearly $1 for $1 with stock). High probability of expiring ITM (>80%). Mostly intrinsic value, minimal time value. (5) CBOE TRADING IMPLICATIONS: Buyers: ITM = conservative (higher probability, higher cost). ATM = balanced. OTM = speculative (lower probability, lower cost). Sellers: OTM = highest probability of profit. ATM = highest premium collection. ITM = highest assignment risk.

chunks.topic: Time-Duration Order Types - GTC, Day, FOK, IOC
chunks.content: CBOE Time-In-Force Instructions: (1) DAY ORDER: Order valid only for current trading day. Automatically cancelled if not filled by market close (4:00 PM ET equity, 4:15 PM ET index). Default order type on most platforms. Prevents stale orders carrying over to next day. CBOE recommendation: Use for short-term tactical trades. (2) GOOD-TIL-CANCELED (GTC): Order remains active until filled or manually cancelled (up to 90 days typically). Does NOT automatically cancel at end of trading day. Survives overnight and multi-day. Broker typically cancels after 30-90 days (varies by firm). Risk: May execute at unfavorable price days later if forgotten. CBOE caution: Monitor GTC orders daily - cancel if no longer wanted. (3) FILL-OR-KILL (FOK): Order must be filled IMMEDIATELY in its entirety or cancelled. No partial fills accepted. Used when you need full size instantly or not at all. Rare in options due to size fragmentation. Best for highly liquid options during active hours. (4) IMMEDIATE-OR-CANCEL (IOC): Order executed immediately for available quantity, unfilled portion cancelled. Accepts partial fills. Example: Order 10 contracts, 7 fill immediately, 3 cancelled. Useful for large orders in less liquid options. More common than FOK. (5) ALL-OR-NONE (AON): Order must be filled completely or not at all, but does NOT require immediate execution. Can rest in book until full size available. Less common in options trading. (6) CBOE BEST PRACTICE: Day orders for active trading. GTC for patient limit orders (but monitor daily). Avoid FOK/IOC unless you understand execution priorities. Most retail traders should stick with Day and GTC orders.

chunks.topic: Position and Exercise Limits - Regulatory Caps
chunks.content: CBOE/FINRA Position Limit Rules: (1) DEFINITION: Maximum number of option contracts (same side of market, same underlying) an investor can hold. Applies to all accounts controlled by same entity (aggregated). Purpose: Prevent market manipulation and concentration risk. (2) POSITION LIMITS BY TIER: Tier 1 (Largest, most liquid): 250,000 contracts (AAPL, SPY, QQQ, etc.). Tier 2: 200,000 contracts. Tier 3: 75,000 contracts. Tier 4: 50,000 contracts. Tier 5 (Smallest, least liquid): 25,000 contracts. Index options: Higher limits (SPX = 500,000 contracts for large indexes). (3) SAME SIDE OF MARKET: Long calls + Short puts = Same side (bullish). Long puts + Short calls = Same side (bearish). Example: Cannot hold 250,000 AAPL long calls + 1 short put if limit is 250,000. Must aggregate across accounts at all brokers. (4) EXERCISE LIMITS: Cannot exercise more than position limit in any 5 consecutive business days. Same limits as position limits. Prevents using exercise to circumvent position limits. (5) CBOE EXEMPTIONS: Market makers and specialists may get exemptions for bona fide hedging. Broker-dealers with regulatory approval. Institutional hedging exemptions possible (case-by-case). (6) VIOLATIONS: Fines from FINRA/CBOE. Forced liquidation of excess positions. Suspension from options trading. Account restrictions. (7) CBOE GUIDANCE: Check position limits before large trades (available on CBOE website). Retail traders rarely approach limits. Institutional traders must monitor actively. Hedge funds aggregating multiple accounts must track carefully.

chunks.topic: Dividend Risk for Call Sellers - Early Assignment
chunks.content: CBOE Dividend Risk Framework: (1) EARLY ASSIGNMENT RISK: American-style call options on dividend-paying stocks face early exercise risk. Highest risk: Day before ex-dividend date. Call holders may exercise early to capture dividend. Especially if: Dividend > Remaining time value in option. (2) EX-DIVIDEND MECHANICS: Ex-dividend date = first day stock trades without dividend. Stock drops by ~dividend amount at open on ex-dividend day. Example: $100 stock, $0.50 dividend → Opens ~$99.50 on ex-div date. Call holder wants to own stock BEFORE ex-div to receive dividend. Must exercise day before ex-dividend (to settle before ex-div). (3) DECISION ANALYSIS: Compare dividend vs option time value. If dividend ($0.50) > time value ($0.20), exercise is optimal. Call holder: Exercise → Receive $0.50 dividend, Give up $0.20 time value, Net gain $0.30. Call seller: Gets assigned, Must deliver stock (buy at market if naked). (4) ITM CALLS AT HIGHEST RISK: Deep ITM calls (delta ~1.00) have minimal time value. Almost certain to be exercised if dividend > time value. ATM/OTM calls rarely exercised early (too much time value). (5) CBOE MITIGATION STRATEGIES: Close short call positions before ex-dividend if ITM. Roll to later expiration or higher strike. Use European-style index options (no early exercise). Sell puts instead of calls on dividend-paying stocks (puts never exercised early for dividends). Sell covered calls (assignment not a problem - own stock already). (6) CBOE MONITORING: Check ex-dividend dates for all stocks with short calls. Brokers typically send warnings for high-risk positions. Most assignment occurs after 6 PM ET on day before ex-div. Position assigned overnight - cannot prevent once notified.

chunks.topic: Corporate Actions Impact on Options - Adjustments and Changes
chunks.content: CBOE/OCC Corporate Actions Protocol: (1) STANDARD ADJUSTMENTS: Options Clearing Corporation (OCC) adjusts option contracts for certain corporate actions. Goal: Maintain economic equivalence before/after corporate action. Not all events trigger adjustments. (2) STOCK SPLITS: 2-for-1 split example: 1 contract of $100 strike → 2 contracts of $50 strike. Contract multiplier remains 100 shares per contract (now 200 shares total). Option symbol changes to non-standard symbol. (3) REVERSE SPLITS: 1-for-10 reverse split example: 10 contracts of $10 strike → 1 contract of $100 strike. Deliverable changes to 10 shares (not standard 100). Contract multiplier adjusted. Creates non-standard contracts (less liquid). (4) STOCK DIVIDENDS: 5% stock dividend: 1 contract now delivers 105 shares. Strike adjusted to maintain value: $100 strike → $95.24 strike ($100 / 1.05). Creates non-standard contract. (5) SPIN-OFFS: Parent company spins off subsidiary. Options deliver parent shares + spun-off subsidiary shares. Example: XYZ spins off ABC at $10/share ratio. 1 XYZ call delivers 100 XYZ shares + proportional ABC shares. Complex valuation - track both components. (6) MERGERS/ACQUISITIONS: Cash merger: Options settle for cash value at merger price. Stock merger: Options deliver acquirer's stock (may be fractional shares). Cash + stock merger: Delivers combination. (7) NON-ADJUSTED EVENTS: Regular cash dividends: NO adjustment (stock drops, options unaffected). Special dividends: May trigger adjustment if >10% of stock value. Stock buybacks: NO adjustment. (8) CBOE WARNINGS: Non-standard contracts become illiquid (wider spreads). Early close-out recommended before corporate action. Check OCC memos for adjustment details (available at theocc.com/memo). Brokers send notifications, but you're responsible for monitoring.
